Plans for a school book exchange to supplement the book
store are being considered by Bob
Mitgang of the Student Council
following a suggestion by Owen
Sear.
such an exchange, if established,
would be a place where a student
could procure second-hand books.
After finishing a course a student
could, under the plan, donate or
sell his text books to the exchange
at a small loss.
Mitgang and Sear propose to
make better book exchanges than
those presently conducted. Not
only do they propose to exchange
books for those of comparable
value, but they also propose to
pay fair prices for used book&

A step in the right direction
The Resolution of the Stiudent Council (see page 1), passed
unanimously, to invite Russian students to the Hopkins, is perhaps
the most constructive action taken by that body within _our recollection. It may be turning point in the role of student government
at this University.
It was not long ago that the Council was debating (heatedly)
the way the doors to Levering Cafeteria should open. The decision to take a stand on an issue of political and,intellectual
significance shows that a considerable degree of maturation has
taken place.
The resolution drafted, reads as follows:
"If the State Department allows the delegation of students
and student editors to, visit the United States, the Johns Hopkins
Student Council will extend an invitation to the delegation to
visit the Hopkins Campus on their tour of American Universities."

NEWS-LETTER

Naval Reserve takes
officer, candidates
The Naval Reserve is accepting
applications from male college students for its Reserve Officer Candidate Program. Students in the
first three years of college who will
not havl reached the 27th anniversary of their birth on the July
1 following graduation may apply,
providing they are members of the
Naval Reserve, or are eligible to
enlist in the N'aval Reserve.
At present, non-veterans must
be under 181
, years of age in
order to be eligible for- a Naval
Reserve enliktment. Candidates
accepted for this program will
continue in college with no restrictions as to the curricula they
may elect to follow. They will attend a Naval Reserve scihool for
eight weeks during each of two
Bummers.
Upon completion of these two
eight week training periods and
graduation from college, candidates will be commissioned'Ensign
in the Naval Reserve. Nonveterans
Who are commissioned under
this
program may be required to serve
on active duty for a period
not to

exceed three years.
Interested students must arrange with this activity, U.S.
Naval Reserve Training Center,
Building Three, Fort McHenry,
Balto. 30, to have their applications processed no later than 14
February, 1955. Further 'information may be obtained by calling
PLaza 2-4561 or by visiting this
Training Center on a Monday or
Thursday between 9 a.m. and
3:30 p.m. or a Tuesday or Wednesday between 2 and 10 p.m.

YEAR 'ROUND SUITS
"Different types of work appeal to
different men," says Donald O'Brian
(A.B., Indiana, '50), in the Traffic
Department with Indiana Bell Telephone Company. "For me, I'll take
a job that keeps me hopping. And
that's just the kind of job I have.
"You'd think that after two years
I'd have all the variables pinned down.
But it doesn't work that way. When
you supervise telephone service for
thousands of different customers whose

needs are always changing, there's
always something new coming up.
"I started with Indiana Bell in 1952,
after two years in the Army. My training program exposed me to many different kinds of telephone work-customer contact, personnel, accounting,
operations. I saw a lot of jobs which
looked as interesting as mine. As
much as I like die kind of work I'm
doing now, I bet I'll like my next spot
even better."

could, under the plan, donate or
sell his text books to the exchange
at a small loss.

make better book exchanges than
those presently conducted. Not
only do they propose to exchange
books for those of comparable
value, but they also propose to

A step in the right direction
The Resolution of the Stiudent Council (see page 1), passed
unanimously, to invite Russian students to the Hopkins, is perhaps
the most constructive action taken by that body within _our recollection. It may be turning point in the role of student government
at this University.
It was not long ago that the Council was debating (heatedly)
the way the doors to Levering Cafeteria should open. The decision to take a stand on an issue of political and,intellectual
significance shows that a considerable degree of maturation has
taken place.
The resolution drafted, reads as follows:
"If the State Department allows the delegation of students
and student editors to, visit the United States, the Johns Hopkins
Student Council will extend an invitation to the delegation to
visit the Hopkins Campus on their tour of American Universities."

Homewood, Baltimore, January 21, 195E

NEWS-LETTER

Naval Reserve takes
officer, candidates
The Naval Reserve is accepting
applications from male college students for its Reserve Officer Candidate Program. Students in the
first three years of college who will
not havl reached the 27th anniversary of their birth on the July
1 following graduation may apply,
providing they are members of the
Naval Reserve, or are eligible to
enlist in the N'aval Reserve.
At present, non-veterans must
be under 181
, years of age in
order to be eligible for- a Naval
Reserve enliktment. Candidates
accepted for this program will
continue in college with no restrictions as to the curricula they
may elect to follow. They will attend a Naval Reserve scihool for
eight weeks during each of two
Bummers.
Upon completion of these two
eight week training periods and
graduation from college, candidates will be commissioned'Ensign
in the Naval Reserve. Nonveterans
Who are commissioned under
this
program may be required to serve
on active duty for a period
not to

exceed three years.
Interested students must arrange with this activity, U.S.
Naval Reserve Training Center,
Building Three, Fort McHenry,
Balto. 30, to have their applications processed no later than 14
February, 1955. Further 'information may be obtained by calling
PLaza 2-4561 or by visiting this
Training Center on a Monday or
Thursday between 9 a.m. and
3:30 p.m. or a Tuesday or Wednesday between 2 and 10 p.m.

YEAR 'ROUND SUITS
"Different types of work appeal to
different men," says Donald O'Brian
(A.B., Indiana, '50), in the Traffic
Department with Indiana Bell Telephone Company. "For me, I'll take
a job that keeps me hopping. And
that's just the kind of job I have.
"You'd think that after two years
I'd have all the variables pinned down.
But it doesn't work that way. When
you supervise telephone service for
thousands of different customers whose

needs are always changing, there's
always something new coming up.
"I started with Indiana Bell in 1952,
after two years in the Army. My training program exposed me to many different kinds of telephone work-customer contact, personnel, accounting,
operations. I saw a lot of jobs which
looked as interesting as mine. As
much as I like die kind of work I'm
doing now, I bet I'll like my next spot
even better."
